907.
MARY GRAHAM
was indicted for
wilful and corrupt perjury at the last sessions at the Old Bailey, on the trial of
William Gosling
.

The record of the conviction of
William Gosling
read.

FRANCIS ROWLEY
sworn.

I know the prisoner, she appeared as a witness on the trial of
William Gosling
, I was present when she was sworn.
Did you see her sworn? - I did.
Are you able to state with certainty what evidence she gave? - No, I cannot.

EDMUND HODGSON
sworn.

Court. Do you know the person of the prisoner? - No, my Lord, I only know that a person of the name of
Mary Graham
gave the following evidence on the trial of
William Gosling
, which I took down in short-hand.

The Short-hand writer here read the evidence of
Mary Graham
, from his original short-hand notes, taken on the trial, as follows, viz.

"
MARY GRAHAM
sworn. - I live in
"Sun Tavern-fields, Shadwell, in Mr.
"Bishop's house; on Wednesday in the
"Whitsun-week, the prisoner's mother
"and me were together, and the two gentlemen
"were together, the prosecutor and
"Mr. Rowley, it was in Guildhall-yard;
"they were discoursing together about the
"young man, and Mr. Rowley said he
"would make forty pounds on him, and
"his mother said she hoped he would not
"make five farthings on him; when they
"came into the hall, there was a man
"named Hart, who told these two gentlemen
"to swear plump against him, or else
"he would not be fully committed; and
"there was another gentlewoman, named

"
Mary Newmarsh
; and Hart said if ever
"a one of us offered to swear in his behalf,
"he would perjure us all three, and they
"would not suffer ever a one of us to
"speak a word; then Hart told Rowley
"and the prosecutor, to swear plump
"against him, or else he would not be fully

"committed:
Mary Newmarsh
was also
"present; Mr. Hart is a constable, and
"wears brown clothes; his mother said,
"gentlemen, do not swear my child's life
"away wrongfully, and Mr. Rowley said,
"I will make forty pounds of him, I only
"want the reward."

Court to Rowley. Are you sure that the person now on trial, was the same person that was sworn under the name of
Mary Graham
? - Yes.

You have heard Mr. Hodgson, the shorthand writer, repeat now, what she swore on the trial, is it true that this conversation passed at Guildhall, in the hearing of the prisoner, or of any other person? - No my Lord.
Did you ever say you would make forty pounds of the prisoner? - Never in my life.
Nor to that effect? - No.
Do you know Hart? - Yes.

Did Hart ever tell you, or Mr. Ambler the prosecutor in your presence, to swear plump against Gosling, or else he would not be fully committed? - No, never any such thing, nor any thing to the same purport, nor I did not know Mr. Hart at this time.
Did any person tell you then, to swear plump against Gosling? - No person whatever.
Had you any conversation with the prisoner's mother? - No, I never spoke to her.
You do not remember her begging you not to swear her child's life away? - No, my Lord, I do not remember any such thing.
Did you answer her, that you would make forty pounds of him, and that you only wanted the reward? - Never in my life.

JOHN HART
sworn.

Had you any conversation with this prisoner, and the mother of
William Gosling
, that was to be carried before a magistrate? - Never, I was in Guildhall-yard when he was brought into the compter; I said to some of my brother officers, that is the man that ran away with a coach and horses; I knew the prisoner again, because I had him in custody.
Did you ever tell Rowley and Ambler, to swear plump against him, or else he would not be fully committed? - Never, I did not know the gentlemen, till they came to find the bill last Friday week.
Did you ever tell any body, to swear plump against him, or any thing to that purpose? - Never, nor any thing to that purpose.
Prisoner. Do not you remember lifting up your hand in our three faces, and saying that if ever a one of us spoke a word for him, he would perjure us all three? - No, never, I saw none but the mother.

BENJAMIN AMBLER
sworn.

Do you know the last witness
John Hart
? - I know him now.

Do you remember any conversation between Hart and you? - I remember him, telling the words to the man just behind me, that he has just told you, about the prisoner being the man that stole the coach and horses.
Did Hart ever tell you and Rowley to swear plump against him, or he would not be fully committed? - No, Sir.
Nor anything to that purpose? - Nothing to that purpose.
Did anybody tell you so at that time? - No, Sir, nobody.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

What I said is certainly true, concerning what them people said, but when Mrs. Gosling found her son was cast to be transported, she has owed me ill-will ever since; and she would not come herself, nor get Mrs. Newmarsh, but she said, I must subpoena her, she said her son was transported on my account; I have nobody belonging to me, but a poor mother, and she is obliged to work for her bread, I have nobody to my character; I get my bread either by the silk business or weaving, I hope you will take it into consideration, I am young with child, and I never was guilty of any such thing before.
GUILTY .

Court to Prisoner. The perjured defences set up on behalf of prisoners, has long been the disgrace of the criminal courts of this country; I have thought it my duty, ever since I have sat in a criminal court of justice, to pay great attention to that circumstance, and to do all that lay in my power to prevent the continuance of so wicked and so dangerous a practice; for the mischief of such perjured defences by no means terminates in an unjust-acquittal, if believed; for that, though a failure of justice, and consequently a great mischief, is but a very small one to the mischief that follows from the frequency of this kind of perjuries, because they induce a court and jury to look with a suspicious eye on the defences of prisoners even when true; they require to be more strongly proved than any other kind of defence, in order to gain credit with the jury, so that the innocent may as often be hurt as the guilty: this is therefore the worst of all offences, except that most horrid of all offences, of which it falls very little short, the crime of murder; and no perjury can be more mischievous than that which frequently occurs in the defence of prisoners. I have therefore made it a point, where there appears strong and cogent grounds before the court on the trial of prisoners, to induce them to suspect, or rather to believe, that a witness is perjured, to put the matter into a way of trial, and to pursue to justice and condign punishment the offenders, if on a full and impartial hearing of a second jury they should be found guilty; and it appears to me that no trial can afford the party accused a better chance of justification, because, before a party can be found guilty, there must be the concurrent testimony of two juries; therefore, it would be idle and nugatory in me, and in the court, to direct a prosecution of that sort, and where it was afterwards supported by clear and satisfactory evidence, to pass a slight sentence on the offenders; for such sentence would be a mockery of justice: however, considering the situation of the prisoner, the court will remember at the same time a degree of mercy with justice, and will nor pass so severe a sentence as might be passed on this prisoner; supposing that the might be ignorant in some degree of the full enormity of her guilt; sentence, however, somewhat severe, it is the duty of the Court to pass, and it is the sentence of the Court, that you,
Mary Graham
, be
privately whipped , and
imprisoned for two years in Newgate .
Tried by the third London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

.

909.
HENRY HARVEY
was indicted for
wilful and corrupt perjury on the trial of
Peter Newberry
and
William Iverson
for a highway robbery, at the Sessions house in the Old Bailey in February Sessions, 1785 *.
* See No. III, Part I. of this Mayoralty.
(The indictment opened by Mr. Garrow.)
Mr. Fielding, of counsel for the defendant. My Lord, I am sure you will not be surprized, in a case of this kind, that I should wish all the witnesses to retire before Mr. Morgan opens.

Court. Let lists of witnesses, except to character, or those that are to prove what passed in Court, be given to each party, and let them all go out of Court; there can hardly be a subject that requires a more serious and solemn investigation for the security of the subject on the one hand, and the safety of the defendant on the other.
Mr. Morgan, of counsel for the Prosecution, then opened the case as follows:

May it please you, Mr. Recorder, and gentlemen of the jury, to favour me in support of this prosecution; you are already informed this indictment is for perjury, committed on the trial of
Peter Newberry
and
William Iverson
; upon that trial, which was for a highway robbery, there was not any witness to the fact of the robbery but the prosecutor himself; there was no other material evidence obtained on the trial but that which was given by Harvey, and that that was material, you will in a few moments, I think, be properly convinced: fear and slight are in general pretty certain signs of guilt; and supposing what the defendant swore on that trial is false, he knew the consequences of his evidence by charging Newberry with having exhibited those two signs of guilt; after stating that he had been to the place, and came back, being asked if he had found either of the prisoners, he answered thus;
"No; I
"went back to Limehouse-corner between
"fifty and sixty yards, where the affair
"happened, and went into a public house,
"and I looked round the taproom, and
"there was the prisoner Peter; but I not
"knowing him, he passed me as I was
"drinking a glass at the bar, and he went
"into the street, and the prosecutor was
"leaning over the post at the corner of
"the street, facing the public house, and
"he called out constable, constable, there
"is Peter, there he runs; I ran after him
"directly, and he ran through a narrow
"passage out of Fore-street into Ropemakers-field;
"he kept running on, but
"I lost sight of him; then he went into
"a little alley, but I took him about ten
"yards from his lodgings, where I had
"been to search for him; the prosecutor
"and the man who called me to his assistance
"were leaning on the nosil of a
"pump; the prosecutor was bleeding; I
"brought the prisoner Peter to him, and
"said, is this the man you want? he said,
"this is Peter, and this is the man that " took me by the throat; and I took him
"away immediately, and put him in the
"cage." After reading the evidence, I need not repeat the observation,
'that it

'was very material?' I shall only observe, that no other evidence respecting Newberry was given but by the prosecutor that any ways affected him. Gentlemen, upon the evidence, I may say of these two men, the prosecutor and the defendant, both the prisoners were convicted: it being afterwards heard by a variety of people, who knew the prisoners, what evidence had been given at the Old Bailey; they insisted upon it that the evidence of both the prosecutor and Harvey in the most material parts were false: an investigation took place, I believe some affidavits were procured, and, if I am not misinstructed, laid before the Recorder, he inquired into the circumstances, and his humanity induced him to procure a respite for these two convicts the day before the day appointed for their execution; the matter afterwards underwent an investigation before the King in Council, and in a fortnight a pardon was issued for the two men. Gentlemen, as this is a prosecution instituted merely for public justice, I shall not make any observations to inflame your passions, or to mislead your judgments, I shall content myself in submitting to you simply, and in as plain a manner as I can, the evidence I mean to produce to you on this occasion. I understand the defendant means to call witnesses, if he does, and I think it necessary and proper, I may trouble you with a few observations on that evidence. Gentlemen, I have no wish on this occasion but that justice should take place; this poor man,
Peter Newberry
, is a hard working labouring man, that lived by cutting wood, and lodged in the house of one
Peter Goodman
; Goodman got his living that way; he had been at work all day, and just before the present defendant, and the said soldier, who alledged he had been robbed were in search of Newberry, Newberry had been out, and was returning home, and a person met him, that I shall call as a witness, and told him there were the old soldier and the defendant Harvey, whom they knew to be a kind of constable, pretty active in taking thieves, and they advised him not to go home; his answer was, I have done no harm, I am not afraid of any one, I certainly will go home: the witness went with him to his lodgings, and saw him go in, and when the prisoner entered the lodgings, the old soldier and Harvey were up stairs searching for Newberry; on his coming in, a woman called to him, and told him here is Newberry; Newberry is come in; upon which the old soldier and Harvey came down stairs, and in the lodgings within the house took Newberry into custody. I am instructed, and shall call another witness, who advised the man not to go home, and his answer will be proved by four or five, if not more, witnesses, who were all present at the time of the caption of Newberry, and they will, upon their oaths, tell you, that Newberry had been taken in the lodgings, and consequently had never been guilty of these two great signs of guilt, fear and flight. Gentlemen, if upon the evidence you should be satisfied, that what the defendant has sworn is false; if you should be convinced that what my witnesses say is true, it will then become your duty to convict the defendant of the crime imputed to him; but if you have any doubt, in that case you will acquit him: I shall press it in no manner, I shall make no observations without I find it absolutely necessary.

JAMES BATTISCOMBE
sworn.
I produce a copy of the record of the conviction of Newberry and Iverson, from the Clerk of the Arraigns.
(Read, and examined by Mr. Fielding.)
Mr. Fielding objected that it was incumbent on the prosecution to state the designation of the persons, and that not being done, it was not sufficiently accurate in the indictment.
The Counsel for the prosecution contended, that they had not taken upon themselves to state the indictment that was tried at the Old Bailey.
The objection was over over-ruled by the Court.

EDMUND HODGSON
sworn.
Court. Do you remember the prisoner giving this evidence? - No, my Lord, I remember the trial, and I remember the prosecutor being ill, but I do not remember the person of the defendant.
Court. Then it is a distinct fact, you must prove by somebody else.

PETER GOODMAN
sworn.
Do you remember the trial of Newberry and Iverson, at the Old Bailey? - I was present there.
Was you there at the time that Harvey was examined? - No, we were not let in till the soldier and Harvey were examined, then we were called.

JOHN OWEN
sworn.
I am one of the keepers of Newgate.
Was you present at the trial of Iverson and Newberry? - I was.
Do you remember Harvey's being examined as a witness? - I do.
Was that the person that was examined? The same.
Do you remember his being sworn? - I saw him sworn in Court.
Mr. Fielding. Do you take upon yourself to say that you remember that particular man being sworn upon this trial? - I do, I knew Mr. Harvey before.

Court to Hodgson.
Read
the whole of the evidence of Harvey from your notes.
The Short-hand writer then read the whole of the evidence of Harvey as in the Sessions Paper, No. III. Part I. folio 342.

Court. Are these the original notes? - They are the original notes my Lord, that I took in short-hand, on the trial of
Peter Newberry
and
William Iverson
, they have been unaltered ever since.

CHRISTIAN GOODMAN
sworn.
I was eighteen the eighth of March.

Are you the son of
Peter Goodman
? - Yes.

Court to
Peter Goodman
. What age is this boy? - He is eighteen.

Where do you live? - I have lived in Lime-house more than a year, I came over from Germany from the army, I brought my wife with me, the boy was born here, I belong to the English army, and I came over here upon the peace; my son was born about a year after the peace in Germany.
Was this boy born in Lime-house parish? - Yes.
Was he christened there? - No, he was christened in the Danish chapel, for I am a Dane born.
Have you any other children? - No more alive than that.

CHRISTIAN GOODMAN
sworn.

Mr. Garrow. Did you know
Peter Newberry
? - Yes.

Do you remember the time he was taken up for robbing
John Lockell
? - Yes.
Do you know this man Harvey? - Yes, Sir, I know him by the sight, but I did not know him before he came with the soldier and knocked at the door first.
When was this? - I cannot tell directly what time.

How long before Peter was taken up? - About a quarter of an hour, I believe it was about six or seven, it was dark, it was the same evening, the old soldier came and knocked and asked for Peter, I mean Lockell, he lodged at our house, says my mother who is there, says he, I want young Peter, what Peter says my mother, says he I wants Peter, so my mother ran down stairs with a candle in her hand and opened the door, so then they went away to the public house.
Who do you mean by they who were with Lockell? - Why, Mr. Harvey, Sir, he stood up against the wall.

How came they to go away? - They went to the public house to look for him, my mother said,
Peter Newberry
was not at home; he was not at home, he was gone to the sawyers, in Rope-makers-fields; I went directly down Rope-makers-fields, to look for
Peter Newberry
, and as I went along, I met him coming in the street.
What was he doing in Rope-makers fields? - He went to the sawyers, and I met him coming from the sawyers.

What did you go for? - To tell him there was
John Lockell
and Harvey to take him up, and I told him to go away.
Had they when they were at your house, told you what they came for? - No, Sir, but I knew they were come to take him up, because I saw Harvey.

How did that lead you to it? - Because he was headborough, and I had seen him take so many people up, I desired him to go back to the place from which he came, but he would not, and I came home alongside of him to my father's house.
How soon after you came home, did you see Harvey again? - He was in our house when me and Newberry came home together.
Was Harvey in the house then? - Yes.

What passed then? - We saw nobody at all, and then when we came back, Peter said, there they are, and so I said, yes, there they are, we went back to our own house, there were several people standing on the outside of the house, and they said, Peter, go away, there is Harvey, and he will take you up.

Did you see Harvey in the street, as you was returning with Newberry? - No, when I came along with
Peter Newberry
, Harvey was in the house.
Did Newberry run when he came back with you? - No.
Did he run through a narrow passage into Fore-street? - No.
Out of Fore-street, into Rope-makers-fields? - No.
When you came to the house if I understand you right, you found Harvey there? - Yes.
Was Lockell there too? - Yes, they were coming down stairs.

Did Newbery go in with you? - Yes, he went in first, and I went in afterwards, upon his going in Mr. Harvey took hold of him by the collar, and said, you are the gentleman I was looking for, and he carried him away to the cage; I went to the cage, and Harvey asked for the keys of the cage to open the door, he continued to hold him all the way.
Did he escape from him at all? - No, he never moved at all.
Mr. Fielding. Little man, do you know a person by the name of Smallwood? - Yes.
Is he in Court? - I believe he is down there.
Have you had any conversation with Mr. Smallwood, little boy? - No, Sir, no further than he said he would subpoenea me to go.

Did not he ask you the story, and tell you what you was to come for? - Yes, he told me I was to come about
Peter Newberry
, because I was with him.
Have not you talked over this affair? - A little, not much, I was at the trial of Newberry, my father was there, I was not called for at that time.
Notwithstanding you was the boy that kept company with Peter in the manner you have related, you was not called at the Old Bailey? - No.

Who told you it would be necessary to speak so precisely to Newberry's getting within the house? - Nobody, I was playing in the street, when Lockell and Harvey came to the door, I was up stairs, my mother looked out of the window, she opened the door, and Harvey went up stairs.
Who did he find up stairs? - My father, sitting by the fire-side chopping of wood, and nobody else was in our house.
Not another man and woman? - There was nobody else but my father and mother, and another young man.
When Mr. Harvey and Lockell were there did you see them or talk to them? - No, not at all.
When was it that you stole out to tell Newberry that they were after him? - I did not steal out, I was determined they should not meet him that night.
You was determined that they should not meet him that night? - Yes.
Did you ask Lockell what he wanted? - No.
He lodged in your house? - Yes.
In what condition was this poor man that night? - He seemed as if he had been scratched by some woman in the face.
Was that all that struck you? - Yes.
Why might he not be scratched by men? - Men never scratch, they were on his cheek: he was standing at the door, I observed it by my mother's candle.

What made you believe if Lockell had been scratched in the face by women, he should want
Peter Newberry
? - He was drunk when he came to the door, he only asked for Peter, and I concluded that they wanted him, and I went out to find him, I found him in Rope-makers-fields, he was coming home then, he went to no other place with me from that in which I met him, till Harvey came and took him into custody, it was about twenty minutes before he was taken, the distance was about the length of the court.
You came from thence home? - Yes.
You apprized him that Harvey was in pursuit of him? - Yes.
Did not you see Harvey behind you? - He was withinside the house, there were several people at the door at the same time.
How came Newberry into the house? - The door was open, and Newberry went in first.
How came he to get in at the door? - Because our door always stands open.
How many people came up to Harvey's assistance? - I cannot say indeed, the only people that were in our house, were my father and mother, and another young man who is gone over to Germany.
You left your father and mother up stairs when Lockell first came? - Yes.

Did your father and mother come down stairs? - Yes, before I went out, and when I came back I saw Harvey coming down stairs, and the soldier before him, I did not see either my father or mother, my father and mother were up stairs, they could not see Newberry come in.
Mr. Garrow. Did I understand you right, that when Newberry came back several people were about the door? - Yes.

Name some of them? - There was
William Stones
, and
Elizabeth Mullett
gave a candle, there was Mrs. Brooks shook hands with Harvey at the door, Mrs. Milledge was looking out of her window, Mrs. Brooks was present both first and last time, that Harvey and Lockell came to the house.
Mr. Fielding. Why did not you tell me of these people being about the door.

Court. He said several people, but you did not desire him to name them? - Mrs. Brooks was there and big with child then, when I returned to the same house with Newberry, she was in the mob, she shook hands with
Harvey
a little before.
What the first time that Harvey came to the house? - Yes, he was twice at the house, she shook hands with him the first time.
Did you see anything of Harvey in the street the first time of his coming? - He did not come into the room, he stood up against the wall, I was standing at the door with my mother.
Where were you when Harvey came first to the house with Lockell to enquire for Peter? - I was up stairs, and my mother too, and I came running down stairs with my mother.
Where did you first see Harvey then? - I saw Lockell first, and then I saw Harvey standing against the wall.
Your father was up stairs then? - Yes, he did not come down with me then.
Did he come down before you went to Peter? - No, Sir.
Pray how came you to judge what they wanted with Peter? - Because I saw Harvey, I thought they would put him in the watch-house.
What for? - I did not know.
How came you to think they would? - Because I saw Harvey there.
How came you to judge that they would put Peter in the watch-house if he had done nothing? - Because I thought he had been wrangling with him.
Had you heard that before now? - My mother said, she would have Lockell beat for going to her customers to sell wood to them.
Had you set Peter to beat him then? - No.

How came you to think at this time that Peter had been doing anything to Lockell? - I did not know anything of it, only that he said he would have young Peter, if he found him anywhere, let him find him where he would he would have him, he said so at the door, when he came first with Harvey.
How came you not to tell this gentleman so just now, when he asked you very particularly? - Because I did not think of it then.
Then your mother had quarrelled with Lockell before this, and wanted him beat? Yes, Sir, that was before he went away, then he took it into his head, and my father was bad a-bed, and he went away.
Had Newberry taken any part with your mother in that quarrel? - No.
Had Peter and Lockell quarrelled at all? - No, Sir, never, they laid together.
What did you and your mother come down for, when Lockell and Harvey came first to ask for Peter? - To open the door for him.
You told this gentleman a little while ago, that the door always stood open? - Yes.
Then what occasion to come down to open it? - It is open, not locked or latched, but it is shut too close, it goes too of itself; it is open always, only not locked or latched.
Peter had lodged there before? - Yes, so had Lockell.
Then he knew that your door stood always open, without being locked or latched? - Yes, but he knocked at the door, he did not push it open.
Though he knew that your house was never locked or latched, he did not attempt to come in? - No, Sir.
But knocked as though he wanted to take up a person in the house? - Yes.
When you came back with Newberry, how long was that after Harvey had been the first time to the house? - I cannot tell, indeed, how long.
Do you know what public house they went to? - Yes, they went to the Pink.
Did you see them go into the Pink? - Yes, Sir, and my father went with him; I did not see my father and them go into the Pink.
How far is the Pink from your house? - It goes down a turning close by our house.
How far altogether may it be from your house? - I believe it may be twenty or thirty yards.
Then I think you say you met Peter about the length of this court from your own door? - Yes, Sir, in Ropemakers fields.

You met him and told him that these people had been looking after him? - Yes, and he said he had done no harm, and he would come home; I was out of sight of my own door; our door does not look towards Ropemakers fields, because the ruins are broad; I went back directly with Peter, I was only gone the time I should be walking the length of this court and back again, after that we came home again.
Then though your father and mother and Lockell had gone to the Pink public house, yet they had made such haste that they had got back again, and had got up stairs? - Yes.

Was your father up stairs then? - Yes, they were coming down and they met Peter in the lower room, and took hold of him, there is no passage, we go through the lower room to the stairs; we all knew he was gone to the sawyers.
Then your father took them to the Pink on purpose to take them out of the way? - Not that I know of.

Do you know
William Iverson
? - Yes.
Did you see him that night? - No, not before he was taken to the cage.
How far did Iverson lodge from you? - I cannot say, it was in Shadwell parish.
Court. Let that little boy go out at that door, and wait till he is wanted.

WILLIAM STONES
sworn.
Examined by Mr. Morgan.

Do you know
Peter Newberry
? - I cannot say that I know him any farther than I heard his name the night he was taken.

Do you know Mr. Harvey? - Yes, I know
Peter Goodman
that keeps a small house there.
Was you there the night that Newberry was taken up? - I was close to the door.
Did you see the old soldier and Harvey? - I saw them in the house.
Once or twice? - I saw them there once, I saw the man go into the house, and he was taken in the house, I am upon my oath.

Did you speak to him going into the house? - I saw him come home, and as he came up to the door, I said Peter do not go in, there is Mr. Harvey looking after you, the man made answer, and said I have done nothing, I will go in; the man went in, I saw him go in.

Where was Harvey at the time that Newberry went into the house? - I cannot tell, I was standing at the door, but I saw Harvey come out, and the soldier with
Peter Newberry
; I saw the three come together out of the house.
Did you go with them? - I went to the watch-house, and I saw Mr. Harvey put him in the watch-house.
Did he escape from him at the time whilst he was going? - No Sir, he went along with him to the watch-house.
Was that after Peter went in, when you had spoke to him? - Yes.
Mr. Fielding. Now my friend Stones, was you at the trial at the Old Bailey? - No, I was not.
What are you? - I am a labouring man.
What sort of labour do you follow? - Sometimes I work in the deal yards, sometimes rope-making.
Or anything I take it for granted; how came you here to-day Account for that, I suppose you was subpoened you will tell me? - Yes.
How came they to find you out? - I do not know, I suppose some of the neighbours told that I was present.

When was Mr. Smallwood lucky enough to find you out? - I have seen him several times, I lived at the bottom of Vine-street, it is about the middle of the street where this
Peter Newberry
lodged.

Was you an acquaintance of
Peter Newberry
's? - No Sir, no further than seeing him in the street? I know as much of Iverson as I know of the other.

Who was it that told you that Harvey was after Peter? - I heard people say there were people after Peter Newberry, but who they were I could not see, it was dark, I could not take particular notice who they were, I heard that Harvey was after
Peter Newberry
, that was the conversation thereabouts.
Did you see Harvey and Lockell when they first gained admission into Goodman's house? - I saw Harvey in the house.
When was it, the first time? - They all three came out together.

Was that the first time that you ever saw Harvey in the house? - I saw the door open, and I saw Harvey and the old soldier looking into the house for
Peter Newberry
.

The door was open then? - Yes, Sir, the door was open then, when
Peter Newberry
went in.
Was that the first time that you saw Harvey or Lockell in the house of Goodman? - No, it was the second time, because I saw him in the house looking for Newberry.

How long might it Be between the two times? - I cannot tell justly the time, it was but a short time, because directly as he went in Mr. Harvey took him directly, I spoke to Newberry at the door, says I, Peter, do not go in, there is Harvey looking after you; to the best of my knowledge I did not see anybody with him but himself; he said, says he, I shall go in, I have hurted nobody, I have done nothing that I am afraid of, I shall go in; he went in directly, and shoved the door open with his left hand, and went in, and Harvey took him.
Had you and Newberry any conversation? - It was not half a minute, there were people that heard the words said, but they could not tell who the person was that said the words.

I take it for granted that there was nobody there but yourself and Newberry? - Yes, there were people looking round the door to see what was the matter, and I stopped at the door, as another might, and I suppose I had not stopped there five minutes before this
Peter Newberry
came down the street to go home, and the people said Harvey was after
Peter Newberry
; to the best of my knowledge Newberry came home by himself, I saw nobody with him, I had not been about this house, take it all together, more than five minutes, I took no notice of the condition of the old soldier; what I have said is truth, I can say no more.

Court. Do you know
William Iverson
? - I know one as much as I know the other.
Did you see Iverson that evening? - No, Sir, I did not see him at all that evening, only Peter Newberry.

You said at first when you was was asked if you knew
Peter Newberry
, that you could not say you knew him? - I never acquainted with him otherways than saying how do you do, of a Sunday.

Did not you know the man very well? - No farther than hearing his name that night, somebody said there is
Peter Newberry
.
You had never heard his name till that night? - No, Sir.
How many people were about the door when Peter came home? - To the best of my knowledge there might be five or six, but I cannot tell who they were, it was dark.

Was you the first that spoke to him when he first came home? - Yes. Sir, directly after he came home I spoke to him, and told him not to go in there for Harvey was after him; says he I have done no hurt to anybody, and I shall go in.
Are you sure you said to him what you have told us? - Yes.
And you was the first that spoke to him? - Yes.

Did the people say any thing to you, when he was coming home? - No, Sir, they said there was Harvey after
Peter Newberry
.
But when you saw Peter coming home, did the people then say anything to you? - No, Sir.
Are you sure of that, now recollect yourself? - Yes, nobody said anything to me, because directly as I came home I spoke to him, and said, do not go in, for there is Harvey coming after you,
The people had been saying before that Harvey had been after Newberry? - Yes, I never heard his name till that night.
Did the people tell you where he lodged? - I knew he lodged in that house where he was taken.

How did you know that that man was
Peter Newberry
? - I knew that was the man that lodged there.
How, as you never heard his name till that night? - The people round the door said here is Peter Newberry coming down the street.
They said so? - Yes.
Why have not you twice in answer to my question said that the people had not said anything to him or to you, and twice you answered me they did not? - He came up to the door, I told him not to go in.

Did the people speak to you, or did they not? - They did not speak to me, I heard them say that Harvey was after
Peter Newberry
; I heard the word mentioned that here was Peter Newberry coming, but I cannot say who they were that said so.

If you had never been in company with Newberry, nor never knew his name till this night, how came you to be the first man that said so very familiarly to him Peter, do not go home, here is Harvey? - I knew him to lodge there in the same street; I live at the bottom of the street, and I look upon it that the house was in the middle of the street where he lodged, I did not know what they had been looking after him for; the reason I bid him go away was, I thought he had been getting drunk, and quarrelling with somebody, and that Harvey had a warrant against him; I know
Peter Goodman
, and the little boy his son, by sight.
How long have you known them? - Living in the same street.
How long? - I have lived there in the street about eight or nine months to the best of my knowledge.
Did you see either of them that night? - Yes, I saw the father.
Where did you see him? - In the street.
Whereabouts? - It was after Peter was taken and gone to the watch-house.
Did you see Harvey and Lockell come to Goodman's house before Newberry came? - No, Sir, I did not.
Did you see the little boy at all? - No.
The door I think you say was not open when Newberry came home? - No, he shoved it open with his left hand to go in, and it was not open then.
Then when was it that you saw Harvey and Lockell about the house, and up stairs for Peter? - To the best of my knowledge it was between seven and eight, or eight.
How long was it before Peter came home? - It might be about three or four minutes.

Who shut the door after that? -
Peter Newberry
shoved the door open with his left hand, and I saw Harvey in the house.

Did you see Harvey and Lockell, the old soldier at all before Peter came home? - When
Peter Newberry
shoved the door open -
Answer the question direct, did you see Harvey and Lockell at all, before Peter came home anywhere? - I did not see them till I saw Newberry shove the door open.
Was there anybody in the passage when Newberry shoved the door open? - I did not see anybody but Harvey and the old soldier.
Where were they? - Just at the foot of the stairs.
Were they below the stairs, or upon the stairs? - Below the stairs.
Not on the stairs? - No.
That was the first you saw of them? - Yes; then as soon as Peter shoved the door open they laid hold of him directly.
Did any body else go in after Peter when they laid hold of him? - No; I did not see any body else go in but Peter.
Did they come out with him directly? - Yes.
If any body else had gone in but Peter you must have seen them I suppose? - Yes.
You did not see Harvey and Lockell go in? - No Sir.
Then they must be there before you came there? - Yes.

You told that gentleman here when he asked you, that you saw the door of the house open and Harvey and the soldier in the house looking for Peter, how came you to say that? - When Peter went in he shoved the door open and then I saw Harvey.
Then it was not true that you saw the door open before. and Harvey and Lockwell in the house? - No Sir.
Court. Let this witness step out and the little boy come again.

Court to little Boy. You saw Stones and
Elizabeth Mullet
in the passage, and Mullet gave a candle, and Mrs. Brookes was there? - Yes.
Now, was that the first time that Harvey and Lockell came to the house, or the second time? - The second time.
Because you know you said that Mrs. Brookes shook hands with Harvey at the door? - Yes, she shook hands with him at the first time.
Was Stones there then? - No sir, he came there afterwards.

Was
Elizabeth Mullet
there then? - She was, but Stones was not; I did not see him come; when I come back with Newberry he was standing in Vine-street, facing our door.
I think you said, that when you came back, there were several people in the passage? - Not in the house.
What do you mean by the passage? - In Vine-street, facing the door.
Then what you call the passage is the street? - Yes.

When you came back with Peter was the door of your house open or shut then? - It was open; somebody had put a bit of wood under the bottom of the door, and it was left open; when I came back with
Peter
the door was quite open.
Then you could see into the house as soon as you came back? - Yes.
Before Peter went in? - No Sir, I was behind Peter; he went in before me; I could see the door was open, because I was behind him all the way.

Whereabouts did you first see Harvey and Lockell? - He was coming down the stairs and Harvey had like to have tumbled over the old soldier to get first; they were both on the stairs when I saw them; I am sure of that; Newberry stopped at the door the value of a minute, then he went in at the door; I went in after him.
Did you speak to Stones at all? - No Sir.
How near was you to the door when he went in? - I cannot tell.

You saw him very well? - I cannot say I saw him, because he was standing among the people; I saw his coat but I could not see his face; I know the colour of his coat; there were a great many people together; I am sure he was there.

Quite sure? - I am quite sure he was there; when Peter came home I heard somebody say, Peter go back; he said, I have done no harm; I believe it was Stones and
Elizabeth Mullet
too, I cannot say it was him, but I heard somebody besides Mullet say so.
Did you know Stones before? - Yes; he lived just by, and had some time.

Did he know
Peter Newberry
? - I cannot tell; I have seen them talk together sometime in the street.

PETER GOODMAN
sworn.
Mr. Garrow. You know Newberry? - Yes.
You remember the time he was taken up? - Yes.
Where was you on the evening of that day? - In my own house.

Was you there when Harvey and Lockell came the first time? - Yes; they came and Lockell knocked at the door, and my wife looked out of the window and said, what do you want; then she went down and opened the door.
You continued up stairs? - Yes.

Did you hear what conversation passed between Lockell and your wife? - Yes; my wife said what is the matter with you, Harvey said, I do not want old Peter, that was me, but I want young Peter, and my wife said young Peter was gone to the Sawyer's, then she called me down stairs, and I came down to the door, and then I saw young Lockell stand facing the door, and Mr. Harvey on the side by the wall, so then Lockell asked me if I knew where young Peter was gone, and I said I believed he was gone to the sawyer, at the public-house; he asked me what public house, I then told him I did not know the house, but I knew the sign, so then I went to the public house to shew it him; the sawyer was gone home to his own house, it is some distance from our house, the sign of the Pink.

How long did you stay at the public-house? - No longer than I could ask for him; they said Peter was gone home; then I went to my own house again, Harvey and Lockell went with me; I went up stairs and began to split wood; Harvey and Lockell went down the street to the water side; they did not go along with me, but in a little while they came back again and came up stairs; Lockell and
Harvey
both together came up into the one pair of stairs where I was splitting of wood; I suppose I had been at home almost a quarter of an hour to my knowledge.
Was Newberry with them at that time? No Sir.
How soon after Harvey and Lockell came back the second time did you see Newberry? - When they came up stairs again I told Lockell to go up stairs to see that he was not come home.

How soon after this did you see Newberry? - About some few minutes after he had been up stairs and came down, Newberry came into the lower room, somebody called Harvey here is Peter; me and Harvey and Lockell were then up stairs.
What became of Harvey then? - Then Harvey went down the stairs and took hold of Peter, and said you are the man I want.
Where was Peter then? - He was in the lower room, in the middle of the room, where he had been sawing wood all day.

Do you know
William Stones
? - Yes; he lives just by; I saw him in the street.
Mr. Fielding. Newberry I understand is a countryman of yours? - No; he is a Swede.
How long has he been on this side the water? - He has lodged with me about half a year.
Your wife and Lockell had had some quarrel before? - Yes, they had.
Did you ever hear her say she would have Lockell licked? - No, I never heard her say so.
What time do you go to bed? - When we leave off work we all go to bed together, sometimes at eight, sometimes seven; I was at the trial at the Old Bailey.

What time did you say Newberry went from home? - It was past six o'clock; Iverson is my countryman, I knew him before; I knew the time he came last from Greenland; I had not seen him in my house in the course of that day.
Did there exist to your knowledge, any intimacy between them? - No.
You did not send your little boy of an errand then? - No.
Do you ever suffer him to be out in the street of a night? - No.
I take it he cannot walk very fast? - No, he cannot.

Where was this boy when Harvey and Lockell first knocked at your door? - He was up stairs binding of wood; the boy was up stairs from that time to the second time that Mr. Harvey came; my wife called me down when they came; I went with them to the Pink, when I came back again I found my boy in the same room.
Those people who came back with you the second time, Harvey and Lockell, they went out of the house again? - Yes.
What became of the boy? - The boy was in doors.
All the time? - Yes, all the time.
From the first to the last time they came to the house, was your son ever out of the house? - At the time they came last to the house I believe he went down stairs.
But did he go out of doors? - To be sure he did.
But how far did he go? - I do not know.
Now how long was this before somebody said, here is Peter? - It was a little before that time that the boy went down stairs.
Court. Then the boy did not go down stairs till after the people called out here is Peter? - Oh yes, he was down before.
How long did the boy go down before the people called out here is Peter? - I cannot tell.
Where was the boy when Peter came in? - He was along with Peter; I stood upon the stairs and saw him.
Any person standing on the outside of the street-door might have seen all the people in the passage? - Yes.
Then, that person might have seen your son as well as Newberry? - Yes.
How long before that moment had you seen him? - Five or six minutes; I cannot say to a minute.
Then your son was lost to your sight for about five minutes? - Yes.
Court. I think you say that you went first with Harvey and Lockell to the public house to look for Peter? - Yes, I left him there, and I came back again, and he was there.
Then he staid till Harvey and Lockell came again? - Yes.
