Continuation of the Trial of
Henry Harvey
.
Court. Then he went down stairs; he had not been down before? - No.
Did Harvey and Lockell go out at all before Newberry came in? - No.
Are you sure of that? - Yes.
Did not you know that the sawyer was not at the public house but in Ropemakers-fields? - No, I did not, I thought he was there.
Did not you know that Peter was gone to Ropemakers-fields after the sawyer? - I knew that a little girl belonging to the sawyer came to fetch him to the sawyer; I did not ask where the sawyer was.
Then how came you to send the little boy to Ropemakers-fields to Peter, to tell Peter that these men were come for him? - I never did send for him; it is not true.

Then you did not tell him to go to tell
Peter
these people were after him while you took them to the public house? - I never did, I cannot tell how the boy came to go of his own head; I did not know what they wanted with Peter; I asked the soldier what he wanted, he said he wanted to see Peter, that was all.
Mr. Fielding. Old fellow, have you had any conversation since you, have been here with that gentleman below you? - No, I have not spoke at all since I have been in Court.
Not since you have been first in Court? - No, indeed I have not.

ELIZABETH MULLETT
sworn.
(Examined by Mr. Morgan.)
Where did you live in January last? - In Vine-street.

Did you know
Peter Goodman
? - Yes.
Did you live any where near him? - Yes, almost facing him.

Do you remember the night that
Peter Newberry
was taken up? - Yes.
Where did you see Peter before he was taken up? - I did not see him any where.
Do you know any thing of his being taken up? - No, Sir, I do not.
Do you know Mr. Harvey? - Yes.
Do you know the old soldier Lockell? - No, Sir.

Do you remember seeing Harvey go to
Peter Goodman
's house? - No.

Court. My girl, you know that
Peter Newberry
was taken up for a robbery? - Yes.
Did you know it the same night that he was taken up? - No, not till afterwards.
Mr Fielding. Have you seen Mr. Smallwood this morning? - Yes.
Court. Now, my good girl, tell me the truth, how came you here as a witness? - Sir, because they came to me.
What were you to come here to prove? - I can tell you, if you please.

Certainly, it is your duty, you are bound by the oath you have taken to tell the truth without fear of any person whatever; you are under the protection of the Court, and you will do yourself honour by telling the truth; you need fear no person whatever? - Sir, I came to my own door, and Mr. Harvey saw me, and he said, my dear, will you lend me the candle, and he took the candle out of my hand, and he went to look for this
Peter Newberry
, and then Peter Newberry came down the street.

Court. Take care what you say; you told me just now you was not present when Newberry was taken up, and did not know of his being taken up till afterwards, now, recollect yourself? - I did tell you so.
Is that true? - Yes, Sir, it is true.

Then, if that be true, then how came you to be here as a witness; what do you know of Mr. Harvey about this business; did you know that night that Newberry was taken up afterwards? - I do not know nothing about what Harvey did that night, I was agoing to tell you that Mr. Harvey said to me lend me the candle.
When was that? - The night the robbery was committed.

Who told you so? - Only I heard people say so; I opened the door, and he came to me, and said, will you please to lend me the candle, and I lent him the candle, and the mean while he went up stairs to look for this
Peter Newberry
; Peter came down the street, and somebody said, go back, for there is Harvey after you, and I heard him, and I said to him, Peter, there is Mr. Harvey after you; says he, I have done nothing wrong, I shall not go, and he went into the house, and Harvey said, you are the man I want.
Who desired you to say this now? - Nobody, Sir.
Who told you this story? - I saw Newberry taken up at Mr. Goodman's house.
Who spoke to you since you have been out of Court the first time? - Nobody.

How came you then, when you was first called up as a witness, to tell me that you did not see
Peter
that evening, that you knew nothing about his being taken up, and did not know that he was taken up till afterwards, how came you to say so? - I do not know, indeed.
Did not you know you was upon your oath? - No, Sir, I did not.
Which am I to believe, what you first swore, or what you swear now, which is the truth? - I cannot say no more than I have said about the candle.
How came you to swear you did not know of it till afterwards? - I made a mistake.
Has either side spoke to you respecting the evidence you was to give or not to give, either of the parties; in the first place, do you know Mr. Smallwood? - Yes, Sir, very well.
Well, has he spoke to you relative to the evidence you were to give? - No, Sir, nor Harvey.
You attended once before the Grand Jury to find the bill? - Yes, I did.
Then, how came you to say you did not know it till afterwards; did any body desire you to say so? - No.

You do not seem to know at all the obligation of an oath, or that you are bound to answer with truth the questions that are asked you; I cannot take your evidence, and you may go; you should think yourself well off you are permitted to go.

TERENCE REYNOLDS
sworn.
(Examined by Mr. Garrow.)
In January last I lived in Vine-street, Limehouse; I know Newberry and Goodman.
Do you remember the night that Newberry was taken up for a highway robbery? - I do, I saw him taken up.

Where was he taken up? - In the house of Goodman; Harvey and Lockell took him together; they all three came out of the house together; I cannot say precisely which took him; after I came in the street I heard an uproar; I lifted up the sash, and I saw Harvey on the opposite side of the way, and a man saying he wanted this man; then in a little while after he got a candle and candlestick to go across the way into this said house, to see for
Peter Newberry
, and in a space of time he came down the street, and some person in the croud said, Newberry, go back, for there is Harvey looking for you; in the next place he said, he did not mind Harvey nor anybody else, he had done no offence to anybody, nor was he afraid of anybody; then from that he came down the street, and clapped his head to the jam of the door, as if listening, and he stood with somebody talking but I could not observe what he was doing, and then he went into the house.

Was the door shut or open? - I was up a pair of stairs, I cannot be positive as to that, he clapped his hand to the jam of the door, and stood a trifle of time, a minute or a minute and a half, and then he went into the house, and as I understood the soldier and Harvey, they endeavoured to take him to the Compter, but they all three came out together in a little space of time.
Mr Fielding. Where did they pick you up? - Sir!

When was it that the attorney or anybody in his business applied to you to come here? - I will tell you Sir, I was in bed, when I was sent to first, and I was called out to a job as I thought, when I went to the house where this attorney was, as I understood to be his attorney, and Mr. I do not know his name, who keeps the public-house, served me with a subpoenea, and gave me a shilling.
Any thing to drink? - Yes, there was three pots of beer, this is three weeks ago, to the best of my knowledge.
Was three weeks ago the first time that was you spoke to? - I never was spoke to, nor never had any imitation about this business.
Do you commonly wear a white frock? - In general.
You saw Newberry in the custody of Harvey in the streets? - I saw him in the street before he was in custody, and afterwards.

What should have led you to the window then? - There was more noise before than there was after, he was in custody, there was an uproar about a robbery, that led me to the window, the man said he wanted his money.
Court. That was publickly made a noise of about the street? - Yes.

Did Newberry come home alone, or did anybody come home along with him? - I saw nobody come home along with him, but I saw him, I know him perfectly well, the street was wide to one person as well as to another.
Did you see anybody go into the house along with Newberry? - No, Sir, he went in voluntarily of his own accord, as I could observe, I saw him plainly go in.
Did any body go in with him or not? - I did not see any person, I did not see any person, I did not know the confidence of the affair, I never expected to come into any behalf till I was subpoenaed.
SUSANAH MILLEDGE sworn.

I know Goodman and Newberry, I was going to bed, I was very big with child, I lived the third door from Goodman's, I heard a noise, I lifted up the sash, I heard Mr. Harvey's name mentioned which made me more anxious to look out of the window, then I saw the soldier, and the people flocking into the house, to see what was the matter, and the man came after they got into the house, I heard Mr. Harvey say to this German woman or Dutch woman, you have conveyed this man away over the pales, and she said, if I am to be believed upon the word of a woman, I have not seen Peter since six to night; in the mean while Mr. Harvey was in the house,
Peter Newberry
and this lame boy came up to the door, and they went into the house, I saw no more.

Mr. Morgan. Where was Harvey when
Peter Newberry
came into the house? - He was in the house, I did not see them come out.
Mr. Fielding. Mrs. Milledge, you was going to bed? - Yes, I was sitting on the side of the bed when the affair happened I continued at the window from first to last about ten minutes.
Not above? - No.
Did you go to bed? - No, I did not, I stood at the window, but I saw no more of them at all.
When was you applied to, to be a witness on this occasion? - Applied to!
Aye, when did anybody wait upon you or come to you, did Mr. Smallwood come to you? - Yes, that was the time the men were in Newgate.

When was you ordered to come here? - I had a subpoena to go to the Old Bailey, upon this trial, I never saw Mr. Smallwood only coming down once or twice or three times, I know Stones, I cannot say whether he was in the street or not, I was not so very particular.
Do you know Reynolds? - Yes, my door is before you come to his, he was at his window the same as I was, I saw Harvey and the soldier go in, but I did not see Harvey come out.
Not at all? - Not at all, I saw the soldier come out dancing with a broom-stick in his hand, I saw them go in between seven and eight.
Court. Mrs. Milledge, your attention was first caught by the noise in the street? - Yes.
You saw the soldier and the people stocking into Goodman's house? - Yes.

After they got in you heard Hervey questioning the woman about letting the man over the pales, and while they were in the house
Peter Newberry
came up the street with the little boy, and went in? - Yes.

Now before that time you knew it was
Peter Newberry
they were after? - Yes. but I could not tell upon what footing.

When you saw Newberry come, and go into the house where they had gone in before, had you no curiosity to see what became of them afterwards? - I saw
Peter Newberry
go into the house, then I quitted the window directly, I went and set myself down, my husband said I should catch cold, and I left the window being very big with child.
How came you to see the soldier come out? - I saw him come out before ever I quitted the window, that was before any of the rest came out of the house, it was after Peter went out of the house.
How long after? - I cannot say, I saw him come out as soon as Peter went in, the soldier came out with a broomstick in his hand, I quitted the window directly.
You were at the window in the whole about nine or ten minutes? - It might be ten minutes.
Then you were attending to what passed till you quitted the window? - Yes, I was.
Did you hear anything said to Peter? - Yes, I heard a person say, Peter, here is Harvey after you, and he said I have done nothing to Mr. Harvey, and he went in, I cannot tell who spoke to him.
Which way did the boy and Newberry come, up the street? - They came right down the street.
Do you know Rope-makers-fields? - Yes, very well.
Did they come from those fields or the other way? - That I cannot say, it is a great wide place before you come to our passage.
Did they come from Rope-makers-fields or the other way? - Sir, it is a long wide place; as I looked out of my window, he came to my right hand; Rope-makers-fields are to the left hand.
Then they came from the opposite way? - Yes.

ELIZABETH BROOKES
sworn.

I live right opposite to
Peter Goodman
's, I knew
Peter Newberry
, I remember the night he was taken up, I saw him that afternoon at work, I did not see him afterwards till he was taken; I saw him at the time he was taken, which was at
Peter Goodman
's house, I heard a noise, and I heard the name of Mr. Harvey mentioned, then I went out, and Mr. Harvey shook hands with me, and said how do you do Mrs. Brooks; says I, how do you do; says I, what is the matter; says he, I do not know, here has been a robbery committed, I do not know what to make of it either head or tail, for they are foreigners; Goodman's door was open, Harvey asked Millett to lend him a candle, then we all went into the house, and the soldier had a broomstick in the house, and a man standing at the door; says he, Peter go back again, here is Harvey after you; says he, I have done nothing to Harvey, I shall go in; I was in Goodman's house at that time, and Harvey and the soldier went up stairs to see for him, Harvey and the soldier continued at Goodman's house till Peter came in; they did not come down at all.

Who opened the door? - Mrs. Goodman, they did not come down stairs till Peter came in, the boy was on the outside of the door; a man spoke to Newberry at the door, and said go back again, here is Harvey after you; says he, I have done nothing I am afraid of, and he pushed his hand against the jam of the door, and pushed the door open and went in, and the soldier and Harvey came down stairs, I was the only one that was in the house besides them; as soon as ever the soldier saw Peter he laid hold of him directly, and said, you must know where William is, he has got my money; when Newberry came in, Harvey and the soldier were up stairs, and were not in sight; just as he came in they came down stairs, and the soldier first seized Peter by the collar, and Harvey caught hold of Peter's arm before he went out of the house, and said he must go with him.
You was not at the trial at the Old-Bailey? - No, I was not.
Court. You saw Harvey and the soldier go into Goodman's house but once? - No, only once.
Did Mrs. Goodman look out of the window before she opened the door? - Yes, and asked who it was, and the soldier I believe it was, said, he wanted Peter.
Then they never went away after that till Newberry came home? - No. Sir, Newberry came in, in the mean time.
Do you know Goodman's little boy? - Yes, Sir, he is a lame boy, walks with a crutch.

Where was he at this time? - He came along the street, not far from the door, I did not see him in the house, I went in with Mr. Harvey and the soldier, and the boy was not in the house to my knowledge, any other than I saw him at the door; if he had been in the house then, I must have seen him, nobody went out of the house.
Was the door open when you came back? The door stood a-jar, anybody might see into the house from the door to the stairs.

HENRY MILLER
sworn.

I know
Peter Goodman
, I live almost facing of him, I was looking out of the window on the night that Newberry was taken up; I saw the officer and the soldier in the house searching for
Peter Newberry
.

What part of the house did you see them search? - By what I could see out of the window, they were up in the garret, and in the chamber, and were coming down stairs when
Peter Newberry
came in? I saw him go in, and he stopped at the door about a minute or two, and then he went in; before he went in I heard somebody say Harvey was after him, but who it was I cannot say; and he said he had done no harm, and he should go to his lodgings; I saw him go to his lodgings, I saw nobody with him to my knowledge.
Mr. Fielding. What might have led you to the window? - Because I heard a bit of a noise at the door.
How many houses are there opposite to this house of Goodman's? - I live at the first house on the right-hand side; I was first apprised between seven and eight, I kept my place at the window.

How should you know that Harvey and the soldier were searching for Newberry? - Because I heard the soldier call out he wanted Peter; somebody came down and opened the door, but who it was I cannot say, then they went in and had a candle of some of the neighbours, but who it was I cannot say; then they went up stairs and searched the garret, and all this while my eyes were upon the house, and coming down the stairs again Peter Newberry came into the house.
Court. Was the door of the house open or shut? - It was open, to my appearance.
Did you see them come out again? - Yes, they came out all together, after Peter went in, and went up the street; I believe they came out in two or three minutes, I cannot say for a minute or two.

Do you recollect who came out first? - No, Sir, I cannot recollect, but I saw Mr.
Harvey
the officer have Peter by the shoulder.
Where was Lockell then? - He came out of the door along with them, they all came as near as could be together: I kept my eye on the door till they did come out.
Did Lockell come out dancing, with a broomstick in his hand? - He had a broomstick in his hand when they came all out together.

Was
Peter Anderson
there at the time? - No, he was not.

PETER ANDERSON
sworn.
Do you know anything about Newberry's being taken up? - I was not there at the taking of him, I was there at the first searching for him.
Mr. Fielding. You remember the night that Lockell was robbed? - Very well I do.
Do you remember the calling out to Harvey, constable, constable? - No, Sir.

Mr. Fielding. Gentlemen, I am now to solicit your attention at this late time of the day, to the case of the defendant that stands before you, and I am sure if it were to strike me as necessary to offer any apology to you for the time I must necessarily take, you would think that apology would be impertinent; for I am sure you will be heartily inclined to give a fair investigation to this case. Gentlemen, although I stand here an advocate for Harvey, and he has a right to expect the exert on of my feeble abilities; yet I go with the learned Judge who tried this cause, in all the observations I have heard him make on the crime of perjury: I perfectly agree that there is nor a crime more deserving punishment; that if committed in the extent suggested here, punishment should fall on the wretch without the accompanying commisseration of any one soul; for if it be true that the man standing before you has committed a wilful and corrupt perjury, on the trial of two men for their lives, my desire is that he should be punished with the utmost severity; at the same time you will be cautious of letting that indignation set aside the weight of the evidence necessary to criminate the person that you have before you: Gentlemen, I cannot say I feel the task upon me to-day of vindicating the defendant an arduous one; because added to the consciousness that I persuaded myself of before I came into the Court, of Mr. Harvey's innocence, I now am more and more confirmed of the propriety of that persuasion from the evidence that has been laid before you: Gentlemen, you know very well that to constitute the crime of perjury, the will must go with the action, and there must be a corrupt motive all through; and whereever therefore that crime is imputed to a man, you will necessarily enquire into the motive: Now what can be the motive of Mr. Harvey for the commission of this crime? Gentlemen, it is necessary for me to state to you a little more at large the nature of this trial, and the reason of Mr. Harvey's being now prosecuted for this as a perjury at the Old Bailey: two men, foreigners, Newberry and Iverson, were tried for a supposed robbery, committed on a man of the name of Lockell; Lockell, at that trial was the prosecutor, and the man before you was the other witness; and my learned friend, with some little ingenuity I must say, introduced that circumstance to you, pointing where the evidence of Mr. Harvey became material, for he seems to suppose that you will be persuaded of Mr. Harvey's being conscious of such materiality of his evidence, when he told you that the materiality of the evidence depended on the circumstance of flight; if he could have established in proof a fabricated lye or falsehood, that would have been a different matter from what you have now to consider; but let not the guilt of the prosecutor Lockell lay at the door of Mr. Harvey; if Lockell was brought to justice, then every man would be satisfied and pleased with the verdict, but there is not the least idea, it is not insinuated that there is any privity at all between Harvey and Lockell, or that Harvey spoke to any other circumstance than merely the apprehension of these two men. Then, gentlemen, permit me to ask you, what could have induced Harvey to go a little beyond the truth in his evidence on this prosecution? I will tell you, because it is the only evidence that can be suggested, in hopes of gaining a part of the reward on their conviction; now, this is the circumstance they are to make out, that he, being apprised of the effect of a flight being given in evidence, had confined his perjury to that idea; trusting to that idea having the effect of convicting the two men at the bar. Gentlemen, that you may clearly understand the nature of this case, let me tell you the story of Mr. Harvey; he was the constable of Limehouse, and the evening, when this robbery was committed, about seven in the month of January, it was dark, he was at that time at home in his house, he was called out by the alarm of a robbery that had been committed; the person supposed to be robbed was very near at hand, and he saw him instantly: upon his coming up to him he told him that he knew the men that had perpetrated the crime, that one was Peter, and the other was Will; that he knew where Peter lodged, and in consequence of this information Harvey went to the house of Peter; now, part of this evidence, that you have heard in support of this prosecution is true, for it hardly ever will be the case, that witnesses will come before a court with a story that will be false throughout; Harvey went with this man to the house of Peter, he knocked; he was answered by a woman from above, and he got into the house; Peter was not to be found there; then Harvey went away; he went to a public house; he had not an idea of missing in this public house the person he went to look for, but as he was drinking a glass of liquor at the bar, Lockell, the prosecutor, from without, called out to him, constable, constable, there goes Peter; there had been a man that left the house merely on the arrival of Harvey, whether it was or was not Peter, I am not able to produce to you, more than the assertion of Harvey; Harvey thinks that man was the person; Lockell calling out to him, he necessarily followed; a chace took place; some times he had him in view, and some times he lost sight of him, but as the man was going towards the house of Goodman, Harvey took hold of him; Harvey's evidence say this, that he took the prisoner Newberry within ten yards of his door, but the evidence of the witnesses in opposition to this say, that Mr. Harvey did not take Newberry within ten yards of the door, but in the very house; now, how could it have entered into the mind of the man before you, that supposing there was a difference, supposing the fact to be, (which I deny) that he was taken in the house, and that Harvey had said he took him within ten yards of the door, could it have suggested itself to a mind like his, that any materiality would have depended on that part of his testimony? Does it strike you so? Here are two or three persons committing a robbery, and immediately one of them is pursued, not the least doubt of the person, the prosecutor swearing positively to his having committed the crime, and by he bye, suppose I say one word, as it is fair here, upon the supposed guilt of these women that are now luckily pardoned; if the evidence of Lockell or his story had gone to complain of one man only as taking this property, I should have thought it fabricated, but when Lockell speaks of two men doing it, either of whom might have proved himself at a different place, I should presume there is a strong reason to suppose Lockell is not hasty in his opinion of these two men; his property was not much that he lost; he was extremely ill used; he was bleeding; they call you evidence to that, and that little boy said his face seemed as if it had been scratched by women; that circumstance convinced me that I had very little to expect from the ingenuousness of a boy so young; he says he is eighteen, perhaps he may, I am sure he possesses the craft of eighteen; but, however, now to return to the situation of Mr. Harvey: in taking this man within ten doors, what could have induced Harvey to have said more to the Court than that he took the man in custody; could it have appeared to him to be a material distinction, whether he had taken him within ten yards or ten feet, or in the house? But I am to call witnesses to you in support of that story that Mr. Harvey has told, and as to the witnesses on the part of the prosecution, I would recount their contradictions, if it was not that the extreme ingenuity of the learned Recorder will, I am sure, amply supply that defect; certain I am, however, that the boy is materially contradicted by the father; certain I am that the boy is materially contradicted by Mrs. Milledge, and it seems to me as if the only evidence I had to apprehend the least possibility of danger from was the evidence of Mrs. Brookes; for, I rely entirely, as to the other witnesses, on the observations which I am sure will be made by the learned Recorder. Mrs. Brookes standing up here, seeing her called on their part, I thought her a decent looking woman, coming with a child in her arms, I thought there would be more regard to truth; and altho' I observed confusion, I thought it did not signify: but, gentlemen, when I call your attention to the circumstance of the case, I am bold to say that her evidence cannot be true, if much of that evidence which has preceded it be true; therefore, wherever there are contradictions as they cannot be both true, the safer way I take it, is to reject such evidence entirely; if the evidence of Goodman be true, the evidence of Brookes is not true; if Brookes's is true, Goodman's is not true; the safer way, and that which has always been taken, as I conceive, by every Jury, is, to reject that testimony entirely; and therefore when I recur to this, that Harvey acted merely in his duty, and if he is here prosecuted without great foundation, deserves the compassion of every man in Court; when I say he has interfered only in his duty, and there cannot be any positive motive assigned to him, except that one of the reward; and when you take into your consideration the probability which yet remains of this robbery's being committed in fact; I say you will attend carefully to the evidence; I say you will dispassionately attend, never presuming guilt, always intending innocence, carefull to give weight to the evidence laid before you, but not to let it hastily involve a man in guilt. On the other side, the evidence I shall lay before you on the part of Harvey will be extremely satisfactory as to the beginning of this business; afterwards I shall lay before you in evidence, a character, which I am sure ought to have, in a case like this, the first weight; not that it will be necessary as I think for your verdict, but that he may return with honour and credit to his neighbourhood. I have the satisfaction of seeing a prosecution like this fairly contradicted and reprobated. The Recorder has with great liberality and ingenuity investigated this business, and he is still to lay before you the result of that testimony; I persuade myself that an equal attention will be paid to our witnesses, and I wish it should; if any of my witnesses should deserve a severity of treatment in cross examination, or if there is any suspicion of their veracity, I wish they may go under every possible trial; but if you think so, the acquittal of Mr. Harvey may perhaps lead to some investigation of the author of this business.

WILLIAM MEREDITH
sworn.

I live at Limehouse corner, at the King's-Arms, the Pink is higher up; I do not know
Peter Goodman
; I know Vine-street; my house is about a quarter of a mile, or not quite so much; I know Mr. Harvey; I remember the evening that Lockell complained of a robbery, it was about eight, Mr. Harvey came into my house and called for a glass at the bar, I went into the bar to serve him, he came in by himself, I filled the glass for him, and he walked into the tap-room, and in came the old Pensioner, and he told me he had been robbed, and had like to have been murdered, and he had a handkerchief or a rag to his head, and that was all bloody, but where it came from I cannot say; Lockell asked me if I would give him a glass, I gave him a glass and he went out, then Harvey came up and drank his glass, and went out after Lockell, and he was leaning on a post, and he called out Constable, Constable, Officer, Officer, there goes
Pedro
the rogue who robbed me, and tried to murder me, there he goes; Pedro he called him.

What did Mr. Harvey do upon that? - He went up the street out of my sight, it was dark; he went directly after him, he run towards Fore-street, that leads up Fore-street; Ropemakers-fields is on the right, there is a passage that leads up Fore-street into Ropemakers-fields; I heard nothing more.
What condition was this poor wretch in? - His handkerchief or whatever he held to his mouth, was all bloody, and he said there had been some blood taken from him.
Mr. Morgan. He was on the other side of the street when you saw him? - Yes.
Then the man called out Constable, Constable? - While the man was going up the other side of the street, Harvey and me came to the door together.

Court. You say that after the old soldier went out he called out as you told us, and was leaning against a post? - I went with Harvey to the door, I saw a man on the other side of the way, I did not know Newberry then.
Was there any man in your house that went out after Harvey and Lockell came in? - I cannot say.
Were there other people in the house? - There were several people in the house; twenty people may go in and out while I am in the bar.

ANN HOLT
sworn.

Do you remember the evening of the robbery? - Yes; I live in Fore-street, Limehouse, I cannot recollect the day, I remember an alarm, I saw Mr. Harvey take a man in Vine-street, but whether that was the man or no I do not know, it was the evening that I heard the noise, I cannot say what noise it was.
Court. Give an exact account of all you heard and saw? - I know nothing at all of it, but that I saw him take a man in Vine-street; I recollect nothing that I heard besides.
Where were you? - I cannot say whereabouts I was , I saw Harvey take hold of a man.
Was it near the house? - No, it was near a pump.
Did not your curiosity carry you a little further than that? - No Sir, my business called me away.
Were there many people about in the street? - There might, I cannot say.
Do you know Newberry? - No.
Do you know his person? - It was dark, he came to our house three days after.
Mr. Garrow. Once in your lifetime you saw Mr. Harvey take up a man in Vine-street? - Yes.
Let me pay you the same compliment my learned friend has paid most of our witnesses; where did they pick you up for a witness, you are a notable one? - I was subpoened.
When? - The 20th of September.
Who first applied to you? - The subpoenea was brought to me, I was surprised.
I rather supect that, you know that is no answer to my question; who first applied to you to be a witness for Mr Harvey; - I know nothing at all about it.
I ask you upon that oath that you have taken, who first applied to you to be a witness for Harvey? - No body at all.
Who subpoenaed you? - A boy brought it to me.
Do you mean to say that before that you had not talked to anybody on this subject? - No, Sir, nobody at all had advised me on the subject.
Did I ask you about advice? - Nobody at all talked to me, I did not tell any body at all, I was not applied to at all to be a witness.

You have sense enough to answer the question, do you mean to state to the Jury, that without anybody having applied to you, and without your having applied to any body, you are come to be a witness for Harvey? - I told no story, that is the true state of the case.

Court. Do attend a little to the nature of the question, it is not whether anybody made any improper application to you to be a witness, but the meaning of the gentleman's question is this, how came Harvey or anybody concerned for Harvey to know that you could say anything upon this subject? - I do not know, I very likely may have said so, upon my honour I cannot tell you, I never troubled my head about the business, Mr, Harvey might have seen me there.
Mr. Fielding. Did not you see him there? - I saw him, but I do not know whether he saw me or not.
Court. Cannot you fix the time when you saw this? - I cannot say.
What month was it in? - I cannot say.
Is it a twelve-month ago, or is it two years ago? - I am sure I cannot tell you, I dare say it is not two years ago, but I cannot say how long ago it is.
Cannot you tell no nearer than that, can you tell whether it is seven years or a week? - I cannot say, there was a piece of work or a noise in the street on that night.
Court. Then your evidence goes for nothing at all.
What was the noise about? - I cannot say.
Did you hear anything about it? - It was not so long ago as seven years, but I cannot say when it was.
Mr. Fielding. Where do you live, young woman? - In Fore-street, Limehouse.
Who with? - With my father and mother.
What countryman is your father? - He is a Dane.
Was your father willing you should come here to day? - Yes, if he had not I suppose I should not have come.
Did not you tell Mr. Harvey that very evening, that the very man he afterwards took hold off, was Peter? - Me! no, Sir. I did not.
Will you call God to witness, girl? - I did not, no, I did not, I would not wish to tell a story for any man living.

Court. You have heard the oath, it is to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth; now if you answer to any question, and say you do not know it when you do, it is perjury? - I say, I do not know what that gentleman asked me.
Was this that you saw three days ago, or three years? - I am very sensible it is more than three days.
Was it so much as three years? - I do not think it was.
Was it two years? - Upon my honour I cannot say.
Upon your oath are not you sure it was less than two years ago? - I do not take my oath at all about it.
But you must take your oath upon it, are not you sure that it was within these two years? - I do not know.
If you do know, I only tell you that you are perjured, and liable to be punished? - But I do not know.
Court. Go about your business.
Mr. Fielding. Ah! go about your business.

WILLIAM GOODWIN
sworn.
I live at Limehouse, No. 90.
Do you live with you father? - No.
With who? - With Mr. Wilson, a hairdresser.
Do you remember the night when there was an alarm of an old man being robbed? - Yes, there was in January.
Do you know Harvey? - I saw him at the Black-horse, in the middle of Fore-street, he was running along, I followed him into Vine-street, I cannot tell how far.

What did you see him do there? - I saw him take a man whom I believe to be
Peter Newberry
, I did not know him, but the last witness
Ann Holt
shewed Newberry to Harvey, then Harvey took him.
At this time had Newberry got into a house? - No, Sir.

It was in the street then where Harvey laid hold of him? - Yes, Mr. Harvey took him by the collar, and led him to a man that was leaning upon the nosil of the pump, which was the prosecutor, he asked him if that was the man he wanted, he said that was Pedro.
What did Harvey do with the man after this? - He took him to Mr. Wetton the constable.
Now little man, if you are not positive speak it, are you sure that Harvey, when Miss Holt said that person was Peter, took hold of him in the street before he got into a house? - Yes.
Did you go down with him to the constable? - Yes.
Did he ever escape from him again? - No, not till he put him in the watch-house.

Mr. Morgan. How long have you known
Peter Newberry
? - I did not know him, I have never seen him since, this was towards the latter end of January.
How came you to take such particular notice of it? - Because it was on Wednesday night, and my master was at his lodge, a freemason's lodge, they meet once a month.
You cannot say the day of the month? - The young woman told Mr. Harvey that was Pedro.
How came she to tell him that? - I do not know.
Where was the man? - Leaning on the nosil of the pump in Vine street.
How far was this young woman from the man? - She was close to him, close to Newberry.
How far from the old man that was leaning on the nosil of the pump? - I cannot tell.
Had she any conversation with the old man? - Not that I have heard.
Newberry was standing still when the young woman pointed him out? - He was standing still, and Harvey came directly and took him.
She and the young man were close together, she and Peter, and she told Harvey that was Peter, and he took him directly? - Yes.
Had they been talking together, the old man and her? - No.
Now tell me how this young woman came to know that Harvey wanted Peter? - I do not know.
Court. Had there not been an alarm that the old man had been robbed? - I had not heard it.

Court to
Ann Holt
. Together with this boy, now madam, will you tell me now whether this was not in the month of January, now your memory is refreshed? - It may be, I cannot say.
Do you know who the man was? - No, Sir.
Did not you upon your oath tell Harvey that was the man? - I did not tell him, that was the man upon my oath, I would not take a false oath.
Nor you never spoke to him at all? - No, I did not indeed, I only saw Mr. Harvey.
Court to Boy. Is this the young woman that told you? - Yes.
Are you sure of that? - She said to Mr. Harvey, that is Peter.

Ann Holt
. I really did not indeed, upon my oath I did not, I did not, indeed I did not speak a word.
Mr. Garrow. I understood you that you did not know Newberry at all? - I really did not know him, indeed.
Nor you did not know his name was Peter? - No, Sir, I never saw the man in my life, nor did not know his name.

Did not you say that you had seen a man since, who you was told was
Peter Newberry
? - I saw him after he came clear, but never before.
Did you know the man before he was taken up? - No, Sir, I did not, indeed.
Mr. Fielding. Young woman, did you hear anybody say any thing about this being Peter? - I do not recollect any thing about it, I did not say a word about it.
Witnesses to the Prisoner's character.

ARMON HILL
sworn.
I believe you are a ship-builder? - Yes, I live in Limehouse, I have known Harvey, the man who sits there, eight or nine years.

Be so good as to inform the Court, and the gentlemen of the Jury, what your opinion is of his character? - I look upon him to be a very fair character; a very honest safe man of a night, and a very diligent sober man, and the only safeguard of the parish of St. Ann, Limehouse, of a night.
Mr. Garrow. The usual question is, what his general reputation is? - A very good one, I never heard any thing against him.
- LYNEY sworn.
I know Harvey very well.
What is his general reputation and character? - An honest just man, I never heard any thing to the contrary.
Mr. WOTTON sworn.
I live at Limehouse. I have known him several years, but about a year and half more intimately; his reputation is a very industrious, honest, sober man; and I look upon him a very useful man.
Mr. WARREN sworn.
I have known him these ten years, a very good character, a very steady, honest, sober man.
Is his general character that of an honest man? - Yes.
The Rev. Mr. YOUNG sworn.

I have known Harvey ever since the summer of the year 1777, I never heard his character impeached in the smallest degree: I myself have always entertained a good opinion of him, I have employed him upon many emergencies; I speak to his general character; he has always been esteemed to my knowledge an honest man.

JOHN STAPLES
, Esq; sworn.
What is the estimate of Mr. Harvey's honesty? - A very good one.
Harvey. I have a great many more witnesses.
Court. Certainly, as far as evidence has weight, we are to take this man's character to be a very good one.

Mr. Morgan. Gentleman, I shall only take up two minutes of your time; on behalf of the prosecution seven witnesses have been called, who have sworn positively to the man's being taken within the house, and that into that house he went a volunteer; some contradictions have arisen, not very necessary for me to repeat, as the Recorder will make his observations very attentively and accurately, as he always does, which will (as they ought) have much more weight with him than any observations that can be made by me; only one observation strikes me, which is, that though several contradictions relative to trifling circumstances have arisen in the course of the evidence, they might be the effect of want of memory, not of design: after having said that, let me advert to the evidence that has been called by the defendant, his character is as good as can be; however there are times when a man forfeits a good character; and, permit me to observe, that the evidence which he has called by way of defence amounts to nothing; recollect in the first place, the evidence that he gave on the trial; now the evidence of the master of the publichouse is this, that he and Harvey walked to the door together, and I take it that had Peter been there, it was impossible but he must have seen him pass by him; whereas the master tells you, that he saw this man, who he says Harvey took on the other side of the way; and his other witnesses flatly contradict each other: Gentlemen, this is the case requiring a great deal of your cool deliberation which I am sure you will give it, if you are satisfied that the prisoner is not guilty, you will acquit him; if you are clearly convinced of his guilt, you must be under a necessity of convicting him.

Court. Gentlemen of the Jury, this trial has taken up a great deal of your time and and attention; but not one moment longer than justice requires; for you have been called upon this indictment to decide upon as important an enquiry as can well come before a Jury and Court of Justice: the prisoner is indicted for perjury; a crime in itself, and under all the circumstances, where it is wilfully and intentionally committed, with a corrupt intention, of very great magnitude; a crime that cuts up by the roots the only bond of confidence that can subsist between man and man, and the only security that we can have for the due administration of justice both between party and party, and between the public and those that are accused of the crimes; but if a perjury of itself, is a crime of such magnitude, when we consider the circumstances under which the present defendant stands charged with that crime it raises it to a height still greater; for the perjury that is charged against the defendant, is stated to have been by him committed upon the trial of two men for a capital felony, and the evidence given against these men, is charged to be false, and to have been knowingly and corruptly given; and therefore if that is true, the whole catalogue of crimes does not contain one of greater enormity, for though, in the denomination of law, such an evidence, if the event of it should be to take away the life of an innocent person, does not come under the legal description of murder: yet, in point of malignity, it seems to be a murder of the foulest die. The question therefore for you to decide this day is, whether the defendant has in defiance of the laws of God and man, committed in the face of his country, knowingly and corruptly, a perjury, with a view to take away the lives of two innocent persons; or whether an innocent man having appeared for the sake of public justice on a former occasion, stands charged with a crime of so much enormity: you therefore will not grudge your time and attention in this enquiry; it has been stated to you in the opening of this business, that from persuasion of the falsehood of the evidence given on the trial of two men, Newberry and Iverson, they have since, upon great deliberation, and with the intervention of those concerned in a judicial capacity, obtained the King's pardon for the offence: the first part of my duty therefore is to tell you that you ought to lay that out of the question; and not to let it make the smallest impression on your minds, for there might be just and wise reasons for that pardon, without the smallest imputation on the truth perhaps of all the witnesses, but certainly of Harvey's testimony; for though his evidence was necessary, yet the truth of that evidence is perfectly consistent with the innocence of both the prisoners; and that that circumstance may be wholly erased from your minds, I think it right to let you know that a conviction of truth or falsehood of Harvey's evidence never came under consideration, when that pardon was the subject of deliberation, but it arises from circumstances in which the account given by Lockell, with respect to himself and his own situation at the time, threw such a suspicion on his testimony, that it was thought unsafe to run the risque of executing two men on the evidence of a single witness, who stood impeached and contradicted: you, gentlemen, are called here to decide, whether the defendant has sworn falsely in the evidence he gave on the trial, and if he did, whether it was done with a corrupt intention: the latter question, which is always the material one to constitute the crime of perjury, will depend on your attention to the nature of the cause, and of the evidence given, and I will therefore state to you, from the indictment, the evidence which Harvey has now been proved to have given on the trial of Newberry and Iverson.
(Here the learned Judge repeated the evidence as read by the Short-hand Writer.)

Now, it is manifest, that the effect of this evidence at the time was to shew a consciousness of guilt in Newberry, and to confirm the testimony of Lockell, for the sum of the evidence of Harvey was, that when he went in quest of Newberry, Newberry slipt out of the public house when he saw the prosecutor come in, and that he actually ran away from him, and escaped, and that he actually took him at some small distance from his lodgings; the effect of that evidence was to shew, that Newberry fled from justice, which is always considered as a circumstance of guilt; then the indictment charges that the evidence was false; that he did not run after him at all, nor did he run away; that he did not keep running, or go into a little alley; and that he did not take Peter about ten yards from his lodgings, but, in fact, he did take him in custody immediately on his coming into his lodgings; now, the evidence given by Harvey on the trial being material in the light I have stated to you, if you believe it to be false, it is difficult to suppose that he could have been mistaken, for it was a fact within his own knowledge, and which it was his particular duty as a constable to attend to, therefore if it was false, and if, instead of pursuing him, and taking him in the street, he never, in fact, pursued him, but took him in his lodgings; Harvey must have known it was false, and if he did, I believe you will not find much difficulty in concluding, that a person, who knowingly gives false evidence against a prisoner, must necessarily do it with an evil and corrupt intention: the principal question therefore for you to decide in this case seems to be, whether the evidence given by Harvey upon this trial was true or false; for if false, the nature of it seems to leave very little room to doubt tha t Harvey must know it, and give it with a corrupt intention; but if it was true, he is an innocent man: the principal question is therefore this, and that upon which the present trial turns, whether you believe, on the whole of the evidence, that he took him in the street, or that he took him in his lodgings? for the story told on the part of the present prosecution certainly does, instead of shewing the consciousness of guilt in Newberry, shew the direct contrary; that Harvey being searching for him at his lodgings, he went home to those lodgings voluntarily, into the very hands of the people that were in quest of him; and that, in that very house, Harvey being in quest of him, took him; a great number of witnesses has been called, most of whom have positively swore to the fact, that Harvey did take Newberry in his lodgings, and not elsewhere; but in swearing to that fact, they have been called upon to state the circumstances; and it is one of the principal advantages in the mode of administering justice in this country, that the examinations of the witnesses are publicly conducted in the presence of the parties themselves, their counsel and agents, as well as the courts of justice, so than an opportunity is given of not resting satisfied with swearing merely to a fact, which, if the depositions were taken in writing, he might do, but there is an opportunity of enquiring into all the cases attending that fact, in order both to judge of the probability and consistency, and to compare that testimony with those circumstances, and with the evidence of other witnesses examined to the same fact; and it is not because one or two, or ten witnesses, positively swear to a particular fact, that a Jury are bound to rely on that evidence, on the contrary, they are called upon to exercise their own understanding, and apply it, and fist out the truth by the comparison of the testimony of the different witnesses, and by an attentive consideration of the evidence that has been related: you will therefore judge for yourselves upon the whole, which of the two facts you believe, to wit, that this man, Newberry, was taken in his lodgings or in the street. The first witness called is
Christian Goodman
, a young looking lad, and his evidence is, that Lockell and Harvey came to the door of his father's house, and knocked at the door; that his mother opened the window, and asked what was the matter; and upon their telling her they wanted Peter, but not what for, she came down, and opened the door for them, and that after going into the house, they went away again; and that when they did go away he himself knowing where Peter was gone to, went to tell him that these people had been after him to take him up, and to advise him to keep out of the way, that he met Newberry a short way from the house and he gave him that advice, but he trusting in his own innocence would go home; the witness went home with him, Lockell and Harvey were returned to the house, and took Newberry as soon as he came into the house, so that by his account they were twice in the house, and had gone away in the intermediate time, and he had taken the opportunity to go and apprize Newberry that they were in pursuit of him; in order to fist the matter more fully, he was much further cross examined, and the first enquiry will be how far the account he gave on his first examination is confirmed or rendered probable by his own testimony on cross-examination; the next enquiry will be how far it is consistent with or contradictory to the evidence of the other witnesses, on the part of the prosecution, he said the door of the house was quite open, and added, their door always stood always open; he describes himself as going out to look for Peter, and his meeting him within not more than the length of this Court off his own door, they not stopping or going anywhere else, but returning directly back, but he says that Harvey and Lockell came twice, and that they went after the first search to a public house, and were come down again and near the bottom of the stairs when he came back with
Peter Newbery
; now it is scarcely possible that this account can in all these circumstances be correctly true, for if they came twice, and went up stairs with a view of searching for them, and his father went with them to the public house their enquiries there, their return, their going up stairs again to make a second search, and coming down again, all must have passed according to his account, within the time that the witness would be walking the length of this Court: when he first said the door stood always open, I dare say it would not suggest to your minds that it was latched, and if it stood always open Lockell must have known it, and therefore would not knock at a door which he knew was always open. The evidence of Stones does not very materially differ from the account given by the boy, he speaks only to the last time of Lockell and Harvey going into the house, he rather increases the time, he says on his cross-examination that Peter came home by himself, and shoved the door open with his left hand; Goodman the father swears that the boy was up stairs till he came back from the Pink, and then he went down stairs, and was absent a few minutes; it is very remarkable that the evidence of the father, whose knowledge if they were relating a true fact, would be more likely to coincide with the son than other witnesses, is more directly contrary to him than any other witness, he describes the time between the first and second search very considerable, he makes it from a quarter of an hour to twenty minutes between the first time of their coming and the time of their apprehending Newberry; but he directly contradicts the evidence of the boy. The story therefore of the father and the boy cannot both be true: by the account of Reynolds, instead of their coming and enquiring for Peter without alarming the house, there was an uproar about a robbery, the man talked about his money, so that the idea suggested by his evidence, and that of the father and the son, who swore he only guessed they wanted Peter, is extremely different. The boy mentioned nothing of Peter's stopping at the side of the door to listen; Brookes also contradicts the boy; the boy says they were upon the stairs near the bottom of the stairs, when he and Newberry went in, and that he saw them the moment he came to the door; the other witness, Mr. Stones, says, they were in the lower room, and this Mrs. Brooks says they were quite upstairs out of sight when Peter came, and that they did not come down stairs till Harvey was called down; another important contradiction is, that if these men came but once, the whole story told by the boy and the father, which is so contradictory in every other respect, must be a fabrication as to the twice coming; here are seven witnesses on the part of the prosecution, who all positively swear, that the man was taken in the house, but in relating the circumstances under which he was taken, it is hardly possible to conceive greater variety in the examination of witnesses, or in the different parts of the examination of the same witnesses. You are to judge whether you think these contradictions could occur in a story that was absolutely true, whether they arise from witnesses speaking to different facts, or whether they arise from witnesses coming to speak one fact, and not being prepared for questions that they have been forced to answer, you will judge. The general observation is with respect to the propriety of the whole story, whether it is likely that this man Lockell, in search of a man, truly or falsely, that he said had robbed him, should go and knock at a door he knew was open. No observation can arise against the defendant from the evidence of
Ann Holt
, but if it did make any impression, it must be the other way; there are witnesses who are called to confirm the evidence originally given by Harvey at the Old Bailey; you are to judge whether you think it likely that a man of that character, for the mere hope of sharing in the reward of blood, should have been wilfully guilty of such a crime; you will take the whole into your consideration; you will take the positive evidence and the contradiction, and whether that is to be imputed to the defect of memory or to fabrication; if you are satisfied that this is not a story against the defendant, but that in point of fact the man was really taken in the house notwithstanding all the contradictions of their evidence; in that case it is a crime of an enormous magnitude, and loudly calls for punishment. If on the other hand, you think that the circumstances of the case, together with the evidence that has been called in support of the testimony of the defendant, though not so numerous as the witnesses for the prosecution, yet tell a story more probable and consistent in itself, and without those contradictions which occur in the evidence for the prosecution, in that case you will find a satisfaction in acquitting the defendant, and restoring him to that credit which he has formerly enjoyed, and it is to be sure a most painful consideration, on the one hand, that a man of an extraordinary character should have been for a very small temptation, guilty of a crime of the blackest die; or that on the other hand, a most wicked conspiracy has been framed falsely to accuse him of that offence.
The Jury retired for about ten minutes and returned with a verdict.
NOT GUILTY .

Court. Gentlemen of the Jury, I am to thank you for the very great attention you have paid in the course of a long and intricate inquiry, and I most entirely concur with the verdict you have given, as it is perfectly consistent with my opinion.
Tried by the third London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.
